awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Economic Optimization of Serverless and VM Cloud Services
awd_abstract_narration:
Cloud computing platforms are responsible for the ever-increasing computation in the United States and the world.  Its uses extend throughout private industry, government, and academia.  These cloud platforms are offered to users via a plethora of computing paradigms and pricing models.  While traditionally, users would pay for the reservation of a computational resource, a recently evolving paradigm, known as Function-as-a-Service (FaaS) or as Serverless Computing (SC), has emerged, where users pay instead only for the time their compute jobs are executing.  This has had significant implications on how these systems are priced, which in turn affects how they are utilized.  This research will use a combination of mathematical modeling, simulation, and prototyping to formally understand the impact that serverless computing has on cloud computing use, both from an economic and engineering perspective.  The research applies a game theoretic formulation in which players are rational agents who are trying to maximize their own individual welfare.  The results will show how cloud computing markets are expected to evolve to accommodate the serverless computing option.  More generally, the results of the research will provide a well-grounded foundation for improved understanding as to how pricing strategies for these differing paradigms impact the use and profitability of both Cloud computing providers and consumers.

The research will expand the nation's understanding of the emerging computational systems that are widely utilized, and will continue to have increasing demand.  From both an economic and engineering perspective, the research will enable a more effective use of such systems, which in turn will increase the efficiency and effectiveness of the nation's computational infrastructure.  The theoretical style of the research is ideal for effective conveyance of the fundamental issues of the topic, making it an important and topical addition to course curriculum. The PIs are committed to broadening participation in this exciting field of research. In particular, they have and will continue to reach out to female students and under-represented minority groups. The project will actively encourage undergraduate research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research accomplished delved into the economic impact of serverless computing (SC) on cloud service pricing and utilization, focusing on rational agents within the cloud ecosystem: cloud consumers who aim for performance at reduced costs and cloud providers striving for profit maximization. The research adopted a multi-faceted approach starting with simple cost models based on real cloud provider data, followed by an analysis blending traditional queueing theory and game theory to grasp the core of the problem. This analysis led to simulations and prototypes, enhancing the understanding and practical application of the models developed.

By exploring this intersection of economics and technology, the research laid a solid foundation for comprehending how optimized cloud systems performed. It shed light on pricing strategies, consumer behaviors, and provider dynamics in response to evolving technological paradigms like SC.

The research further explored the realm of net neutrality, a concept aimed at maintaining an open and innovative internet environment. While content quality preservation aligned with net neutrality principles, the role of differential pricing, notably zero-rating, remained contentious. Zero-rating involved offering free internet access under specific conditions, often leading to differentiation among users or content providers.

The study modeled zero-rating dynamics between internet and content service providers, analyzing the impacts on different market players, ranging from startups to established entities, employing game theory frameworks akin to the prisoner's dilemma to understand decision-making and utility gains or losses. It revealed that zero-rating, if allowed, could favor high-income CPs but often disadvantaged low-income counterparts, potentially impacting market competitiveness negatively.

As a third thrust, the research evaluated the efficiency of Bloom Filters in serverless systems, particularly their role in monitoring cached items. Bloom Filters were space-efficient data structures used for membership testing in sets, albeit with a potential for false positives. The research challenged the conventional worst-case analysis of Bloom Filters, which may have underestimated their efficiency in real-world network applications.

By refining the analysis to account for Bloom Filter recycling and the average false positive rate, the research presented more accurate performance metrics. It introduced renewal and Markov models to compute average false positive rates, highlighting improvements in efficiency by up to 30% compared to worst-case scenarios. Additionally, the research addressed the false negative rates induced by recycling Bloom Filters, providing approximations and bounds for their analysis, which aligned closely with simulation results.

Overall, this research contributed significantly to understanding the economic, regulatory, and technological dimensions of cloud computing, net neutrality, and efficient data structures like Bloom Filters in contemporary computing environments.
